intro: Erysimum hirtum, commonly known as the hairy wallflower, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright, branched stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces bright yellow, four-petaled flowers that bloom in early spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered with short, stiff hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Erysimum hirtum thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and borders.
